metadata.titleEn: Multi-scale surface flux and meteorological elements observation dataset in the Hai River Basin(Huailai station-automatic weather station-40m tower, 2018)
metadata.description:
This dataset obtained from an observation system of Meteorological elements gradient of Huailai station from January 1 to December 31, 2018. The site (115.7923° E, 40.3574° N) was located on a cropland (maize surface) which is near Donghuayuan town of Huailai city, Hebei Province. The elevation is 480 m. The installation heights and orientations of different sensors and measured quantities were as follows: air temperature and humidity profile (3, 5, 10, 15, 20, 30, and 40 m, towards north), wind speed and direction profile (3, 5, 10, 15, 20, 30, and 40 m, towards north), air pressure (in the box), rain gauge (3 m, south of tower), four-component radiometer (4 m, south of tower), two infrared temperature sensors (4 m, south of tower, vertically downward), photosynthetically active radiation (4 m, south of tower, vertically upward), soil heat flux (3 duplicates, -0.06 m), a TCAV averaging soil thermocouple probe (-0.02, -0.04 m), soil temperature profile (-0.02, -0.04, -0.1, -0.2, -0.4, -0.8, -1.2, and -1.6 m), soil moisture profile (-0.02, -0.04, -0.1, -0.2, -0.4, -0.8, -1.2, and -1.6 m).
The observations included the following: air temperature and humidity (Ta_3 m, Ta_5 m, Ta_10 m, Ta_15 m, Ta_20 m, Ta_30 m, and Ta_40 m; RH_3 m, RH_5 m, RH_10 m, RH_15 m, RH_20 m, RH_30 m, and RH_40 m) (℃ and %, respectively), wind speed (Ws_3 m, Ws_5 m, Ws_10 m, Ws_15 m, Ws_20 m, Ws_30 m, and Ws_40 m) (m/s), wind direction (WD_10 m) (°), air pressure (press) (hpa), precipitation (rain) (mm), four-component radiation (DR, incoming shortwave radiation; UR, outgoing shortwave radiation; DLR_Cor, incoming longwave radiation; ULR_Cor, outgoing longwave radiation; Rn, net radiation) (W/m^2), infrared temperature (IRT_1 and IRT_2) (℃), photosynthetically active radiation (PAR) (μmol/ (s m-2)), average soil temperature (TCAV, ℃), soil heat flux (Gs_1, Gs_2, and Gs_3) (W/m^2), soil temperature (Ts_2 cm, Ts_4 cm, Ts_10 cm, Ts_20 cm, Ts_40 cm, Ts_80 cm, Ts_120 cm, and Ts_160 cm) (℃), soil moisture (Ms_2 cm, Ms_4 cm, Ms_10 cm, Ms_20 cm, Ms_40 cm, Ms_80 cm, Ms_120 cm, and Ms_160 cm) (%, volumetric water content).
The data processing and quality control steps were as follows: (1) The AWS data were averaged over intervals of 10 min for a total of 144 records per day. The missing data were denoted by -6999. (2) Data in duplicate records were rejected. (3) Unphysical data were rejected. (4) The data marked in red are problematic data. (5) The format of the date and time was unified, and the date and time were collected in the same column, for example, date and time: 2018-6-10 10:30. Moreover, suspicious data were marked in red.
For more information, please refer to Guo et al. (2020) (for sites information), Liu et al. (2013) for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: Aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) is a key factor in surface flux estimations with remote sensing algorithms and/or land surface models. Originally, z0m is defined as the height where the wind speed, given by the extrapolation of the logarithmic wind profile, becomes zero. According to numerous observations, the variation range of z0m over different surfaces is large, from an order of 1.0 m over urban areas and mountainous areas, to an order of 0.1 mm or even 0.01 mm over smooth water body surfaces, ice and snow surfaces. The traditional way to calculate z0m is based on the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory, using wind profile measurements. In practical applications, especially for remote sensing models and land surface models, it is difficult to obtain z0m for a local or regional scale based only on station observations. Former researchers have proposed some parameterizations between the aerodynamic roughness length and the land surface properties [e.g., vegetation height, leaf area index (LAI), etc.], since wind turbulence is controlled by the structure and spacing of roughness elements (plants and other obstacles) on the land surface, and z0m describes the roughness characteristics of a surface.
research objective: Based on the data of the Xiaotangshan Experiment (Changping District of Beijing, China), which was conducted in 2002, 2004, and 2005 respectively, the objectives of this paper are: (1) to calculate z0m over different surfaces and analyze the directional characteristics of z0m over heterogeneous surfaces using an analytical footprint model; (2) to relate the estimated z0m over heterogeneous surfaces to roughness element characteristic factors, and present a heuristic parameterization of z0m as a reference for model parameterizations.
challenges: More data is needed for further discussions.
methods: This paper calculates z0m over several land surfaces, with 3 years of experimental data from Xiaotangshan. Individual z0m over each surface component (patch) is calculated firstly with the characteristic parameters of the roughness elements (vegetation height, leaf area index, etc.), then z0m over the whole experimental field is aggregated, using the footprint weighting method.
dataset: This experiment was carried out at the Xiaotangshan Experimental Station for Precision Agriculture (40°10′41′′N, 116°26′52′′E, 35 m above sea level) in Beijing. The observation period in 2002 was from 26 March to 23 April and the land cover was bare soil. In 2004, the experiment was carried out from 30 May to 7 July. In the southern sub-plot field, the land cover was bare soil between 30 May and 11 June, while the maize plants started emerging around 12 June. In 2005, the experiment was from 1 May to 10 June and the experimental layout was almost the same as that in 2004.
findings: The results show that z0m is direction-dependent, mainly due to the heterogeneity of the size and spatial distribution of the roughness elements inside the source area along different wind directions.

background: For surface flux measurements, large aperture scintillometer (LAS) has become more and more popular in recent years. Compared with traditional observation techniques, it can measure surface fluxes on a larger scale (500 m to 10 km). At present, LAS observation is not common in China.
research objective: The daily and monthly variation of HLAS is analyzed. And the observation differences between eddy covariance system and LAS, need to be studied further combined with footprint model and energy unbalance of eddy covariance system observation.
challenges: There is much less agreement on the form which universal stability function fT should take. Further more, since the iteration process of HLAS can not be convergence when low wind speed and very stable conditions appearing at night, Wm \ - 5 is specified.
findings: Sensible heat flux (H) calculation with the LAS data of above measurements shows that the beam height of LAS and wind speed are sensitive factors for sensible heat flux measurement (HLAS), zero-plane displacement height is crucial unless the beam height is much larger than it, and Bowen ratio needs to be determined accurately over wet surface, while air temperature, air pressure and aerodynamic roughness length are not sensitive for HLAS. According to the observations mentioned above, LAS can measure surface fluxes both over homogeneous and heterogeneous surfaces.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used for measuring aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) over heterogeneous land surfaces?
Example.Answer: The Xiaotangshan Experiment conducted in 2002, 2004, and 2005 used wind profile measurements and characteristic parameters of roughness elements like vegetation height and leaf area index to calculate z0m over different surfaces. The z0m over the entire experimental field was aggregated using a footprint weighting method.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when using large aperture scintillometer (LAS) for surface flux measurements?
Example.Answer: A challenge in using LAS for surface flux measurements is the lack of agreement on the form that the universal stability function fT should take. Additionally, the iteration process for sensible heat flux (HLAS) calculation can fail to converge under low wind speeds and very stable nighttime conditions.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a dataset that includes multi-layer soil moisture and temperature observations for agricultural research?
Example.Answer: The dataset collected from the automatic meteorological station at the 40m tower in Huailai Station includes multi-layer soil moisture and temperature observations. Soil moisture sensors are buried at depths of 2cm, 4cm, 10cm, 20cm, 40cm, 80cm, 120cm, and 160cm, while soil temperature probes are placed at the same depths.

Definition.Question: What does 'aerodynamic roughness length (z0m)' mean in the context of surface flux estimations?
Definition.Answer: Aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) is a key factor in surface flux estimations using remote sensing algorithms or land surface models. It defines the height where the wind speed becomes zero based on the logarithmic wind profile. The variation range of z0m is large over different surfaces, from urban areas to smooth water bodies, and it is traditionally calculated using the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory with wind profile measurements.

Definition.Question: What is the significance of 'large aperture scintillometer (LAS)' in surface flux measurements?
Definition.Answer: The large aperture scintillometer (LAS) is significant in surface flux measurements as it can measure fluxes on a larger scale, from 500 m to 10 km, compared to traditional observation techniques. LAS is sensitive to factors like beam height, wind speed, and zero-plane displacement height, making it effective for measuring sensible heat flux over both homogeneous and heterogeneous surfaces.

Definition.Question: What does 'footprint model' mean in relation to calculating aerodynamic roughness length over heterogeneous surfaces?
Definition.Answer: A footprint model is used to calculate aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) over heterogeneous surfaces by analyzing the directional characteristics of z0m. It aggregates z0m over an entire experimental field by weighting individual z0m values from each surface component based on the characteristics of roughness elements like vegetation height and leaf area index.

Comparison.Question: How do data collection methods for meteorological elements using automatic weather stations compare with those using large aperture scintillometers in terms of scale and accuracy?
Comparison.Answer: Automatic weather stations measure meteorological elements such as temperature, humidity, and wind at specific heights and locations with a high-frequency output, allowing detailed local measurements. In contrast, large aperture scintillometers measure surface fluxes over larger scales (500 m to 10 km), providing broader spatial coverage. The automatic weather station's accuracy is suitable for capturing detailed vertical profiles, whereas large aperture scintillometers are noted for capturing surface fluxes but may face challenges in stability under certain wind conditions.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences and similarities between the data processing techniques used in datasets collected from automatic weather stations and those collected from experiments like Xiaotangshan for aerodynamic roughness estimation?
Comparison.Answer: Data processing for automatic weather stations involves ensuring completeness, removing duplicates, and flagging questionable data, with a focus on continuous, high-frequency data output. In contrast, the Xiaotangshan experiment specifically processes data for aerodynamic roughness estimation, involving footprint modeling and parameterization of roughness elements like vegetation height. Both methods emphasize data quality control, but the experimental dataset requires additional calculations to relate roughness length to land surface properties.

Interpretation.Question: What does the observed sensitivity of sensible heat flux measurements to factors like beam height and wind speed in large aperture scintillometer data tell us about the challenges of measuring surface fluxes on heterogeneous surfaces?
Interpretation.Answer: The sensitivity of sensible heat flux measurements to beam height and wind speed indicates that accurate measurement of surface fluxes on heterogeneous surfaces requires careful consideration of these factors. The zero-plane displacement height is crucial unless the beam height is significantly larger, and the Bowen ratio must be accurately determined for wet surfaces. This sensitivity highlights the challenges and complexities in capturing representative flux measurements across varying terrain and surface conditions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors cause variability in aerodynamic roughness length measurements across different surface types in meteorological observations?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Variability in aerodynamic roughness length measurements across different surface types is primarily caused by the heterogeneity in size and spatial distribution of roughness elements, such as vegetation height and leaf area index, which affects wind turbulence and consequently the roughness characteristics of a surface.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes discrepancies between eddy covariance system and large aperture scintillometer measurements in surface flux observations?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Discrepancies between eddy covariance system and large aperture scintillometer measurements in surface flux observations can be attributed to differences in measurement scales, the sensitivity of LAS to beam height and wind speed, and the energy imbalance often observed in eddy covariance systems, which requires further study using footprint models.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of using multiple layers of air temperature and humidity measurements at different heights on understanding atmospheric dynamics?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Collecting air temperature and humidity at multiple heights allows for a detailed vertical profile of the atmosphere, which can provide insights into thermal stratification and vertical mixing processes. This can improve the accuracy of atmospheric models and help understand local microclimate variations.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the inclusion of soil moisture and temperature measurements at various depths affect the modeling of soil-plant-atmosphere interactions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Incorporating soil moisture and temperature measurements at different depths helps to characterize the soil thermal and hydrological regimes, which are crucial for understanding soil-plant-atmosphere interactions. This can lead to better predictions of plant growth and water use efficiency, as well as improve land surface models.

Causal Consequence.Question: What effects do rigorous data quality control processes have on the reliability and usability of meteorological datasets?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Rigorous data quality control processes, such as ensuring completeness, removing duplicates, and filtering out erroneous values, enhance the reliability and usability of meteorological datasets. This can lead to more accurate analyses and predictions, thereby supporting better decision-making in both research and practical applications.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the rationale for calculating aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) over different surfaces, and how does it contribute to remote sensing algorithms or land surface models?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The rationale for calculating aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) is to improve surface flux estimations with remote sensing algorithms and land surface models. z0m is crucial because it describes the roughness characteristics of a surface, which are influenced by the structure and spacing of roughness elements like vegetation. Understanding z0m helps in assessing the impact of different surfaces on wind turbulence and thereby aids in the parameterization of models, especially when station observations are not available for local or regional scales.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can the aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) be calculated and parameterized using remote sensing models and land surface properties?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) can be calculated using wind profile measurements based on the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory. Parameterization involves relating z0m to roughness element characteristic factors like vegetation height and leaf area index, and using footprint weighting methods to aggregate z0m over the experimental field.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methods are employed to ensure the accuracy and reliability of surface flux measurements using large aperture scintillometer (LAS) systems in heterogeneous land surfaces?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Methods to ensure accuracy include analyzing the daily and monthly variation of sensible heat flux (H), studying the differences between eddy covariance systems and LAS, and considering factors like beam height, wind speed, and zero-plane displacement height. Additionally, the Bowen ratio must be determined accurately over wet surfaces.

Enablement.Question: How does the use of a large aperture scintillometer (LAS) enable the measurement of surface fluxes over larger spatial scales compared to traditional methods?
Enablement.Answer: The LAS system allows for the measurement of surface fluxes over larger spatial scales (500 m to 10 km), which is more extensive than traditional methods, making it suitable for both homogeneous and heterogeneous surfaces.

Enablement.Question: What data processing methods enable the quality control and standardization of high-frequency meteorological observations?
Enablement.Answer: Data processing involves ensuring the expected number of daily data points, marking missing data, removing duplicate records, and eliminating data that exceed physical or instrumental limits, with standardized formatting for date and time.

Judgmental.Question: How effective do you find the existing data collection methods for measuring aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) over heterogeneous surfaces, considering both remote sensing models and land surface models?
Judgmental.Answer: The existing data collection methods, primarily based on wind profile measurements using Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory, face challenges in capturing z0m at local or regional scales. This is particularly true for heterogeneous surfaces, where the variation in roughness elements like vegetation height and leaf area index influences wind turbulence. Parameterizations relating z0m to these surface properties can be effective, but require comprehensive data collection across diverse land surfaces to enhance model accuracy.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what strategies could enhance the reliability and comprehensiveness of meteorological datasets collected from automated weather stations, especially those similar to the 40m tower setup in Hebei Province?
Judgmental.Answer: To enhance reliability and comprehensiveness, it is vital to implement robust data quality control measures, such as marking missing data and eliminating physically implausible values. Additionally, increasing the frequency of data collection and integrating various sensors for multi-layer observations can provide a more detailed dataset. Cross-referencing with other data sources or remote sensing data can also improve accuracy and fill data gaps, thereby strengthening the dataset's utility for broader applications.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how data from multiple sensors on a meteorological tower can be integrated and processed effectively?
Assertion.Answer: The integration and processing of data from multiple sensors on a meteorological tower involve ensuring data quality control, like handling missing data with specific markers, eliminating duplicate records, and filtering out data beyond physical meaning or instrument range.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the methods used for processing and quality controlling meteorological data collected from automated stations, focusing on the strategies for handling missing or erroneous data points.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection method involves ensuring that there are 1440 data points each day, with missing data indicated by -6999, and removing duplicate records. Data points that are clearly beyond physical meaning or instrument range are deleted. The format for date and time is standardized, and questionable data is marked in red.

Request/Directive.Question: Please investigate the challenges and potential solutions for calculating aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) using wind profile measurements in diverse land surface conditions.
Request/Directive.Answer: The traditional method for calculating z0m is based on the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory using wind profile measurements, but it is challenging to obtain z0m for local or regional scales based solely on station observations. Parameterizations between z0m and land surface properties, such as vegetation height and leaf area index, are proposed, as wind turbulence is influenced by the structure and spacing of roughness elements on the land surface.

Request/Directive.Question: Please assess the advantages and limitations of using large aperture scintillometer (LAS) for surface flux measurements compared to traditional observation techniques in various environmental conditions.
Request/Directive.Answer: Large aperture scintillometer (LAS) can measure surface fluxes on larger scales (500 m to 10 km) than traditional methods. However, the calculation of sensible heat flux (H) with LAS data shows sensitivity to factors like beam height, wind speed, and zero-plane displacement height. The Bowen ratio also needs accurate determination over wet surfaces, but air temperature, pressure, and aerodynamic roughness length are less sensitive for LAS measurements.
